Insights into Western Culture: Academic, Social and Popular
Insights into Western Culture: Academic, Social and Popular
Love and Desire in Literature and Film
Love and Desire in Literature and Film

In a world where the human attention span seems to be shrinking,student will expand their creativity and home their skills with language by reading,studying,and writing these micro-stories.Student will leave the course with a better sense of how to say more by writing less

This course provides a variety of English and American literature and film in which the sea acts as the setting,a body of symbolism,a mystery ,the agent of divine wrath,a human challenge,a means of escape,and a reason to reflect on the human relationship to nature. Writers have long found the sea and the modes of human interaction with it a cause for wonder and reflection.

The course focus on helping the student to acquire and to apply communication skills essential to the techncal and professional writer.The emphasis in this course is on learning to plan and pproduce effective professional documents that address a specific audience,use plain language in clear sentences,employ conventional formats and organization,imply a tone appropriate to the author's purpose and intended audience,meet workplace standards of grammar and punctuation,and incorparate engaging visual aids.
Do Good Fence Male Good Neighbors? Neighborliness and Counties,Large and Small
Do Good Fence Male Good Neighbors? Neighborliness and Counties,Large and Small

This course looks at the ways in which states use the social and personal idea of neighborhoods and turn them into foreign policies.Using documents,speeches,trade data and analysis of language used to describe "neighbors",This course will seek to unite students' understanding of foreign policy and social interaction.
Mirrors on Ourselves:Mutual Image of Chinese ,Americans,Africans
Mirrors on Ourselves:Mutual Image of Chinese ,Americans,Africans

People look in the mirror every day;but seldom dose a people spend time thinking about how they as a nation appear to other peoples.This course will be an overview of the ways in which Americans,Chinese and Africans are perceived bby each other .American have a long history of strong images of Chinese,many of them naive and inaccurate  which nevertheless form part of the background of US-China relation
This course is for any student with an interest in culinary culture around world.The course focuses on the impact of culinary culture on human society .

This course is for any student with an interest in business etiquette and different cultures around the world.This course aims to raise students' awareness of cultural differences in various parts of world and develop students' competency as the global business critizens in 21st century.The course focuses on the protection of international etiquette and socio-cultural norms observed by a specific culture or country.
Standing out in the American Job Market: From Resume to Interview and Beyond
Standing out in the American Job Market: From Resume to Interview and Beyond
This class is a hands-on approach to developing approach that will get students noticed in today's job market in the United States.Covering all aspects of the process.

Presented from an operational perspective, this course introduces students to the
interdisciplinary field of cybersecurity, discusses the evolution of information security into cybersecurity, and explores the relationship of cybersecurity to organisations andsociety. Students will be exposed to multiple cybersecurity environments,technologies, processes, and concepts, analyse the threats and risks to/in these environments, and understand how to develop an appropriate strategy to mitigate potential cybersecurity impacts in the modern information environment.

This course is designed to provide both executives and an overview of the issues that are related to leadership and management of companies and entrepreneurships in a global world.For executives and general managers, the course offers frameworks for evaluating and guiding innovative and entrepreneurial activities in their organizations. Tthe course offers frameworks for organizing and understanding the management challenges related to practicing entrepreneurship and innovation is an age of globalization. The focus is on decisions made by organizations as they attempt to deal with the challenges posed by various functional areas of an organization and in global markets.
Information Management in the Building Industry

Information Management in
the Building Industry

In this course students will be exposed to BIM in 5 phases: initialization, design development, system integration, construction, and facility management. Students will learn the methodologies, standards, tools and trends for all 5 building phases. This course is relevant to multiple disciplines involved in, building design, business, and facility management.

The course will teach students passive and active design responses for real world msecurity threats. In addition to classical security methods, this course will discuss the latest United States Department of Defense: anti-terrorism, force protection, and data security standards. This course is relevant to multiple disciplines involved in,building design, business, international studies, and law.

Entrepreneurial Approaches to the Experience Economy
Entrepreneurial Approaches to the Experience Economy

This course is about using entrepreneurial spirits and methods to be successful in business,with an emphasis on the production and consumption of consumer experience,because economics have moved from manufacturing to service to the newest global experience economy.
This course examines the importance of modern South and Southeast Asian history.
The Rise and Fall of Rome (753BC–AD476)
The Rise and Fall of Rome (753BC–AD476)
This course provides an introduction to Roman history
Ecocriticism: Literature, Film and the Environment

Ecocriticism: Literature, Film
and the Environment

The goal of the class is to rethink current approaches to the evironment and to understand ongoing discussions on environmental ethics and politics.We wil read,among other,works by Emerson,Thoreau,Leoppold,Coetzee,Barros and analyze movies such as Bird and Avatar.

This course is an economic analysis of several processes that prepare the labor force of the next generation for their economic roles. How a child is raised; how different children move through different educational patterns; how after completing their education, how new workers choose their jobs, and how the new workers are prepared for their roles by the institutions that hired them, are some questions that will be answered in this course. The course will use different economic perspectives, including but not limited to perspectives of Feminist, Neoclassical, Keynesian and Marxist schools

In capitalist economy, some workers earn million dollars per month while others earn wages that can barely support them. There are several explanations from different schools in economics, using education, class differences, productivity differences, race and gender factor and many different factors to explain for wage differences. This course will state the scope and different
dimensions of wage differences in capitalist economy using data. It will introduce different explanations of wage differences, and it will cover possible effects of different factors like minimum wage, free education and unions, etc. on wage differences.

In this course we will learn to think critically about the diversity of life,how it evolved,how it is sustained,and why it is important ,with a focus on Chinese biodiversity and issues.we will use theories and models as unifying principles to help us understand and make predictions regarding natural processes and phenomena.
Communication and Public Culture in Africa
Communication and Public Culture in Africa

The course will examine how Africans use oral literature, digital and social media, folklore, art,textile, music, and public cinema as expressive forms of discourse about state and society. Case studies include Nigeria, Ghana, Francophone Africa, Lusophone Africa, and Southern Africa.

The course will examine evolution of African media systems from colonial to post-colonial systems, state-press relations, and media coverage of external relations. Media coverage of external relations will include coverage of China’s engagement with Africa over the last 10 years.

This course will explore selected moments in world history since 1500,including an examination of new maritime exploration beginning in the late 1400s,changing patterns of trade and exchange between hemispheres;revolution and independence miments;the rise and fall of enpires ;and increasing globalization .

This course will explore selected moments in world history prior to 1500,including an examination of the development of settled river vally societies;incresing trade links across Eurasia; the foundations of empires;and the rise and spread of universal religions.Students will read primary sources in English.This will serve as an introduction to type of survey course in world history to 1500 that many student may need to take if they pursue a degree at an American university and will expose them to different formats of learning lectures,discussion of primary sources,and assessments.

"Africa and the World" is a multi-disciplinary course which will explore Africa's internal dynamics, as well as the processes by which the continent became integrated into thelarger world system. Because the continent of Africa is so vast and the experiences of Africans so diverse, during each lecture session, I will draw on case studies from West,East, Central, and South Africa to offer an overview that will provide a narrative of a given theme.

Gender-aware and women-centered approaches to the study of African history present African women as active agents of historical progression and change. This approach to African women's history represents her collective strengths, diverse situatio

Dr. Swisher’s research focuses on three related areas, community development, capacity-building for community based organizations, and food systems. Her research is largely associated with developing the research capabilities of her graduate students, although she also serves as co-PI for several grant funded projects with colleagues at the University of Florida and other universities. All of her research addresses issues surrounding the sustainable development of local communities, particularly local and regional food systems and community-based resource management. These are the research topics that form the common thread in the research conducted by her students and by most of the students on whose committees she serves.
The Philosophy of Contemporary Global Art
The Philosophy of Contemporary Global Art

This course will use illustrate lectures to introduce philosophical models important to the understanding ,appreciation, and analysis of visual art forms produced by artists in multiple countries and across multiple continents.
Appreciation of Popular Music in Cinema
Appreciation of Popular Music in Cinema

This course will use illustrated lectures and live screenings of selected scenes from
Hollywood Cinema. The lectures and screenings will feature Hollywood and arthouse
created films that utilize popular music (music appropriated for use in films) to
dramatically create and structure visual narrative, storytelling, drama, and emotional
content in cinema.

The course overviews the significance floors across the globe in recent history,the current situation,what lessons have been learned,and prospects for the future including recommended education and necessary adaptations for coping with future floods.This course is supported by strong visual material that tell engaging stories and would be of interest to students in earth and environmental sciences,engineering,social sciences including economics and psychology,planning, law or environmental policy and other areas.

This course discusses inference and evaluation using earth and environmental science framework for investigation.This course discusses the scientific method ,the path to explanation and solution,issues with collecting facts,analyzing facts,and evaluation through a multiple working hypothesis approach.This course would be of strongest interest to students in earth and environmental sciences

An overview of the theories and methods used by Cultural Anthropologists to study several universal subsystems found in all human societies, including economic systems, family systems, health care systems, and religious systems.   Attention will be given to the special variants of these systems found in Chinese society, comparing and contrasting them to similar systems found elsewhere.
Effective Teaching Methods for English as a Second/Foreign Language
Effective Teaching Methods for English as a Second/Foreign Language

This course focuses on research-based effective instructional strategies and methods for teaching English as a second or foreign language.  Topics include grouping for instruction and student interaction, comprehensible input, and higher order thinking skills.

This course focuses on an overview of multiple and various educational philosophies and systems, including the US, western Europe (Finland), Latin America, and Asia. This course address the socio-cultural context of education, and uses a framework for comparing across educational systems.

The purpose of this course is to understand and apply (1)the basic  principle of effective public speaking,(2)the principle of audience analysis and message preparation,and (3)critical listening skills as they apply to public speaking. An informative and persuasive speech ,and an impromptu speecj will be prepared and delivered by each students,depending upon class size.

This course covers:Basics of nonverbal communication .Touch.Personal space,Territory and Evironment.Physical Appearance .Body Alterations and Covering .Kinesics.Vocalis .The application of nonverbal communication in various contexts.There will be in-class activities,observational studies to complete ,and questions for thought to answer for each unit.

Using the WHO guidelines for HPV prevention, the 3 day course will look at issues such as burden of disease, diagnosis, treatment, counseling on various HPV clinical states. An emphasis will be placed on HPV prophylactic vaccines and cervical cancer screening activities. The 3 day course will have been piloted at Senghor University, Alexandria, Egypt in April 2014

The first 2 days will be about discussing about sexual practices and risk factors counseling. Special attention to sexual identity and orientation issues will be discussed. The third will be about point of care testing about HIV.  Pre test and post test counseling will be discussed.

This introductory course deals with the numerical solution of non-linear equations in one variable ,polynomial interpolation and numerical differentiation and integration.This course is based on chapters 2 to 4 of "Numerical Analysis"by Richard L.Burden  and J.Douglas Faires.The course material will be illustrated throughout with numerous MATLAB example.

This course treats the numerical solution, using both direct and iterative methods, of linear systems of equations Ax=b. Direct methods covered include Gaussian elimination (with pivoting) and the use of LU and Cholesky factorizations, the latter for symmetric positive-definite systems. Iterative methods include those of Jacobi, Gauss-Seidel and Successive Over-Relaxation (SOR). This course is based on chapters 6 and 7 of “Numerical Analysis” (9th edition) by Richard L. Burden and J. Douglas Faires.

Based on a proactive approach to the management of people, assessment of the global environment and strategic alignments. The design and execution of human resource management strategies. How to think strategically about aspects of managing the organization's human assets. Reward systems, performance management, high-performance human resource

Current training and development methodology, techniques and aids. Topics include learning theory, determining training needs, writing objectives, designing training programs using outside resources and training transfer and evaluation.

The process for conducting appraisals that increase quality and productivity. Review of performance management options and techniques and principles for effective performance management. Define performance factors and employee development plan through the appraisal process. Write the appraisal and prepare for an appraisal meeting. Communicate constructive performance feedback.
Palliative Care for Those with Life-Limiting Illnesses
Palliative Care for Those with Life-Limiting Illnesses

Death is an inevitable reality for all human beings. This reality becomes even more salient in health care situations where curative approaches are no longer possible or desirable. There is, however, the potential to moderate and soften the effects of the physical and emotional distress that often accompanies the inevitable and unavoidable reality of death and dying. Health care professionals have a key role to play in this regard. This course will provide students with the opportunity to learn about symptom management and psychosocial care of people living with life limiting illness.
Quantitative Research Methods in Health Care
Quantitative Research Methods in Health Care

The quantitative research process will be described, including literature review, conceptual frameworks, research design, sampling, data collection strategies, analysis of research data, and ethics.
Upon completion of this course, the student will be able to:
-Understand the steps of the quantitative research process
-	Distinguish descriptive research from quasi-experimental and experimental research
-	Develop a meaningful and worthy clinical problem statement
-Develop a clear research question(s)/objectives(s) with testable hypotheses
-Identify and describe the best research design to address a research question(s)
-Identify and describe the appropriate participant sample for a study
-	Identify and describe the best materials/questionnaires and data collection approaches
- Choose an appropriate data analysis procedure
-	Apply ethical principles to research examples.

The course addresses the opportunities and challenges in polymer recycling. It begins with framing the drivers (financial, environmental, consumer awareness) for recycling of polymers, explaining the difference between post-consumer and post-industrial waste and some basic concepts on polymer properties which are required to understand the science of polymer recycling.The course goes on to describe the many opportunities (mosty financial and environmental in nature) and challenges (mostly technical/scientific in nature) in using recycled polymers. We go deeper into the scientific aspects, analyzing the existing problems and how they could be (or have already been) solved. Finally, some case studies will highlight current research: mixed polyolefins (post-consumer) and carpet waste (post-industrial). This course is primarily aimed at engineering students.

Additive manufacturing (AM) is a booming field, which opens many possibilities for rapid prototyping, product design, mould making and material development. With AM technologies, complex 3D products can be manufactured in polymers, metals or ceramics in a matter of hours.The course will start by explaining the (commercial and technical) benefits of using AM and the basic principles of all AM technology. We will then go deeper into the different AM technologies, their working principle, benefits and challenges.Finally, some case studies will be worked out with examples of real industrial and
research projects and products.
This course is primarily aimed at engineering students.

Polymer processing is a major industrial component for the manufacture of consumer products. The most widely used techniques are injection moulding and extrusion, which are well-known technologies. Recent developments in science however, have opened the way to more advanced aspects of these technologies.
This course will give a short introduction on the general principles of polymer processing and injection moulding/extrusion. It will then go on to discuss several advanced polymer processing techniques such as the use of hybrid moulds, micro moulding, micro-extrusion for 3D plotting, processing of nano-compounds and bio-based polymers.For each technique, we will go into the working principle, the materials which can be processed, the advantages and remaining challenges for this specific technology. Each chapter will be highlighted with specific case studies and products.
This course is primarily aimed at engineering students.
European History from the French Revolution to the Fall of the Berlin Wall
European History from the French Revolution to the Fall of the Berlin Wall

Design optimization: is the systematic application of numerical algorithms and techniques to engineering systems to assist in improving system performance,weight,reliability,cost,etc.Optimization methodolodies can be applied during product development stage to ensure that the finished design will have the highest performance,highest reliability,lowest weight, lowest cost,etc.This course provides a glimpse into the consideration,algorithms,limitations,and applications of numerical optimization.

A detailed examination of the main statistical learning techniques, with emphasis on their mathematical basis as well as how they relate to each other. This is a technical course, and it is aimed at Master level / high undergraduate. Comfort with statistical and linear algebranotation is expected, but can be refreshed by individual students from introductory sources.

This is a less technical course than the Statistical Based Machine Learning course abouve,athough some of the algorithms discussed can be difficult. It is aimed at early ,master level/mid to high undergraduate. Comfort with statictical and logical notation is expected but can easily be refreshed by individual students from introductory sources.

It analyses enabling and disabling factors for collaboration and partnerships between state, market and civil society actors. The course draws on experience of different countries and regions, e.g. the German Energiewende (Energy Shift Policy) and Emission Trading Schemes in Europe. There is ample evidence of reform-oriented policies and projects in many countries, including China. Yet, it is challenging to achieve a high level of compliance, coherence, cooperation and implementation across sectors and regions.
Neurosustainability The Effects of Architecture and Design on Our Nervous System
Neurosustainability The Effects of Architecture and Design on Our Nervous System

This course therefore gives the fundamental orientation an architect and designer needs to understand this relationship in order to create spaces that are useful for the purposes they want to support.
The course consists of practical experiences, lectures, workshops and presentations.
